metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: automatic weather station of Heihe remote sensing station, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Heihe remote sensing station from January 1 to December 31, 2022. The site (100.4756° E, 38.8270° N) was located on artificial grassland in Dangzhai Town of Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1560 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (1.5 m, north), wind speed and direction (10 m, north), air pressure (2 m), rain gauge (0.7 m), four-component radiometer (1.5 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (1.5 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, -1.6 m), and two photosynthetically active radiation (1.5 m, south, one vertically downward and one vertically upward).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_1.5, RH_1.5 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, Ms_160 cm) (℃),on the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m2)).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2022-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Disjunctive.Question: Are the data collection methods in the field primarily based on automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, or scintillometers?
Disjunctive.Answer: automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, scintillometers

Concept Completion.Answer: field and remote-sensing observations, numerical simulations, eddy covariance systems, scintillometers

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to observe soil temperature and moisture profiles in arid regions?
Example.Answer: In the Heihe River Basin, soil temperature and moisture profiles are observed using soil temperature and moisture probes buried at various depths, such as 0cm, 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm, and 160cm, as part of an automatic weather station setup.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert systems?
Example.Answer: One challenge faced in collecting hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert systems is the ecological environment degradation, such as drying up of rivers, degradation of vegetation, and land desertification, especially in inland river basins along the Silk Road.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset containing long-term energy and carbon flux observations in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A dataset containing long-term energy and carbon flux observations is available from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin, which includes data from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations established since 2012, capturing energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, and additional hydrometeorological data.

Definition.Question: What is the role of an oasis in the context of arid and semi-arid regions and their ecological systems?
Definition.Answer: An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that not only forms the core of regions’ ecological environment but also underpins their economic development. In China's arid regions, oases, which constitute less than 10% of the total area, support more than 90% of the population. They are crucial for maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity within the oasis-desert system.

Definition.Question: What are the typical components included in a dataset for studying oasis–desert interactions?
Definition.Answer: A typical dataset for studying oasis–desert interactions includes long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. This encompasses data such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles, and groundwater table data.

Definition.Question: What challenges do inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face in terms of ecological environment degradation?
Definition.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face challenges like the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are particularly prevalent in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin.

Interpretation.Question: How might the methodologies used in data collection from automatic weather stations contribute to understanding the interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The methodologies used in data collection, such as using automatic weather stations to gather hydrometeorological data and eddy covariance systems for flux data, allow for a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. This is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development in these areas.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential implications of using long-term observational datasets from oasis–desert systems for understanding global carbon cycles?
Interpretation.Answer: Using long-term observational datasets from oasis–desert systems can provide insights into these areas as carbon sinks, which significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions. This understanding is increasingly important in the context of the global carbon cycle and achieving goals related to carbon peaking and neutrality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it crucial to include both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems when collecting datasets for energy and carbon exchange studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Including both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems is crucial because it provides a comprehensive understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in different types of ecosystems, which is essential for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and ensuring ecological stability and sustainable development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the deployment of multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations in the Heihe River Basin for data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Multiple stations are deployed to capture the spatial variability and complex interactions of hydrometeorological factors, energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes across diverse conditions in the middle and lower reaches of the arid regions, which are influenced by the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of implementing strict data quality control measures on the reliability of meteorological datasets collected in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing strict data quality control measures can enhance the reliability of meteorological datasets by ensuring completeness and accuracy, as seen in the methodology where missing data is flagged, duplicates are removed, and data exceeding physical or instrumental limits is discarded.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of long-term observational datasets affect the understanding of carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of long-term observational datasets can significantly improve the understanding of carbon exchange by providing comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes over time, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential implications of using automated weather stations for collecting high-frequency data in remote or arid areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using automated weather stations for high-frequency data collection in remote or arid areas allows for continuous monitoring of meteorological parameters, which can result in a detailed understanding of environmental processes, as demonstrated by the 10-minute interval data collection and subsequent data processing and quality control.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the main objectives of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives include achieving a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas to recognize interactions, protect ecological stability, support socioeconomic development, and contribute to carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a comprehensive observation network in arid and semiarid regions, such as the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to maintain a comprehensive observation network to study the complex interactions within oasis–desert systems, address ecological challenges like land degradation and desertification, and support sustainable development and ecological security in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures for ensuring data quality and handling missing data in meteorological observations within arid and semi-arid ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality is ensured by verifying the presence of the expected number of daily data points, specifically 144 per day, due to 10-minute intervals. Missing data are marked with -6999, duplicate records are removed, and data that exceed physical or instrumental limits are deleted. Problematic data are highlighted in red, and consistent formatting for date and time is maintained.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can eddy covariance systems and scintillometers be employed to collect long-term data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Eddy covariance systems and scintillometers are used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. These instruments are part of a suite of observational datasets that also include auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters, collected from multiple stations in the Heihe River Basin.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are utilized to integrate hydrometeorological data with soil and vegetation parameters for comprehensive ecosystem analysis in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Hydrometeorological data, such as radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles, along with gradients of air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and direction, are collected using automatic weather stations with 10-minute intervals. This information is supplemented with soil moisture profiles and vegetation parameters, enabling a comprehensive analysis of ecosystem dynamics in arid regions.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques and technologies enable the comprehensive observation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: The comprehensive observation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems is enabled by the use of long-term datasets collected from artificial and natural systems, including half-hourly turbulent flux data acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, as well as hydrometeorological data observed from automatic weather stations at a 10-minute average period.

Enablement.Question: How do the conditions of arid and semiarid inland river basins impact the data collection methods for monitoring ecological changes?
Enablement.Answer: The conditions of arid and semiarid inland river basins, such as ecological environment degradation and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, necessitate robust data collection methods like continuous long-term observations and the use of multiple meteorological stations to effectively monitor changes in energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do auxiliary datasets, such as vegetation and soil parameters, enable a more detailed understanding of oasis–desert interactions?
Enablement.Answer: Auxiliary datasets, including vegetation and soil parameters, complement the primary data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, providing a more detailed understanding of oasis–desert interactions by offering insights into the ecological and physical characteristics that influence these exchanges.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset of oasis–desert systems not achieve a comprehensive understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange interactions?
Expectation.Answer: A comprehensive understanding of these interactions in oasis–desert systems is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases. Long-term observations are indispensable to achieve this quantitative understanding.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when using automatic weather stations to collect hydrometeorological data in arid and semiarid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing ecological challenges such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which could impact the data collection process and the accuracy of the data collected by automatic weather stations.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that oasis–desert areas significantly impact the carbon balance of arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers, thereby significantly affecting the carbon balance of arid regions and playing an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using automatic weather stations in capturing comprehensive hydrometeorological data in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Automatic weather stations are effective in capturing comprehensive hydrometeorological data as they provide consistent, high-frequency observations crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. The stations collect data such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and meteorological parameters, which are indispensable for long-term studies in these regions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data from various soil temperature and moisture sensors can be effectively managed and quality-controlled in such a large-scale observation network.
Assertion.Answer: The data is processed by ensuring daily 144 data points (every 10 minutes) and marking missing data with -6999. Duplicate records are removed, and any data exceeding physical or instrument limits are deleted. Questionable data is marked in red, and date and time formats are standardized.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how long-term observations from an oasis–desert ecosystem can contribute to addressing ecological stability and socio-economic development challenges.
Assertion.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems, which helps in maintaining ecological stability, supporting sustainable development, and achieving carbon peaking and neutrality goals.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the importance of having both artificial and natural systems in datasets for understanding oasis–desert interactions.
Assertion.Answer: Including both artificial and natural systems in datasets provides a comprehensive view of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which is essential for recognizing interactions and ensuring ecological stability in oasis–desert systems.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the typical data collection methods used for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid and semi-arid oasis-desert systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Typical data collection methods in this field involve long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers. Hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, are observed from automatic weather stations. Vegetation and soil parameters also supplement these datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please detail the challenges associated with data collection in arid and semiarid inland river basins and suggest methodological approaches to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in arid and semiarid inland river basins include ecological degradation, drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, increased desertification, and frequent dust storms. Methodological approaches to address these challenges may involve establishing comprehensive monitoring networks and using advanced technologies such as remote sensing to enhance data accuracy and coverage.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets related to oasis-desert energy and carbon exchange observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies for expanding or refining these datasets include increasing the number of observation sites, integrating additional data sources such as remote sensing and satellite data, enhancing the temporal resolution of data collection, and incorporating new technologies for measuring hydrometeorological and biophysical parameters. Collaboration with data centers to facilitate data sharing and archiving can also support dataset refinement.
